messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Raimon
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Rich, Mon is pattern, so this would be a lightening pattern. Gordon ... From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf
messages.messageBody:
Hi Rich,

Mon is pattern, so this would be a lightening pattern.

Gordon

-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of Richard Turner
Sent: Monday, May 29, 2006 3:26 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Raimon

This question would mostly be for Gordon and Jim as it relates
directly to a NTHK Kanteisho, but anyone else who see's fit to throw
in can do.

I have a kanteisho which describes the tsuba theme as Raimon. As I
understand it, in Japanese, Kaminari (雷) means thunder and/or
lightning depending on the situation. If we want to distinguish
thunder and lightning, we say Raimei (雷鳴) and Inaduma
(稲妻)
respectively and Raiden (雷電) for thunderbolt.

But in case of Raimon (雷文), does it mean an old Chinese form
or
pattern which seems to express lightning.

Cheers all

Rich







Yahoo! Groups Links

messages.subject: Raimon
messages.msgSnippet: This question would mostly be for Gordon and Jim as it relates directly to a NTHK Kanteisho, but anyone else who see s fit to throw in can do. I have a
messages.messageBody:
This question would mostly be for Gordon and Jim as it relates
directly to a NTHK Kanteisho, but anyone else who see's fit to throw
in can do.

I have a kanteisho which describes the tsuba theme as Raimon. As I
understand it, in Japanese, Kaminari (雷) means thunder and/or
lightning depending on the situation. If we want to distinguish
thunder and lightning, we say Raimei (雷鳴) and Inaduma (稲妻)
respectively and Raiden (雷電) for thunderbolt.

But in case of Raimon (雷文), does it mean an old Chinese form or
pattern which seems to express lightning.

Cheers all

Rich
